review_blob: 98 Harvest ale, and I just couldnt bring myself to give it anything less than a 4. It pours a unique shade of hazelnut with a light dusting of off white bubbles that delicately rim the glass. The aroma was a robust combination of sour cherries, dried fruits and caramel with the subtle aroma of spices. However, the flavor profile was completely different. Milk chocolate and toffee blend with roasted malts and coffee grounds. The mouth feel is round, smooth and delicately decadent and one that hides the 11.5% alcohol beautifully. For a 13 year old beer this bad boy held up. It was damn good.

12oz bottle compliments of the masters at Avery. Pours a hazy but vibrant ruby red/mahogany with subtle carbonation and just a light layer of off white head. On the nose you get the most intricate combination of sour cherries and wild yeast. The aroma prepares the palate for the crisp flavor of tart wild cherries, cranberries and just a hint of plum. Tart through and through with an incredibly long finish that lingers on the surface of the tongue. If Avery doesnt stop theyre going to start making people look bad.

12oz Can. Light body, almost no carbonation, very little head but with a rich amber/brown color with almost the slightest of yellow kind of pilsner tint to it. The nose has a strong aroma of caramel, malt, vanilla, asparagus, with just a little citrus and pine. The alcohol content is hidden very well. Flavors of pineapple(hophead21112), fresh citrus, and the slightest touch of kiwi are the most prominent. Its not as hoppy as I would have expected from Oskar. The finish suggests a bit of vanilla and a bit of pine but fell a little short. Still a good brew just not as big as these boys usually do it.

750ml Bottle. Pours a rich mahogany with a red hue in the light. A cloudy, medium body with just the slightest amount of carbonation but a generous head of off white bubbles. The nose is delightful. The smooth texture of milk chocolate and vanilla are complimented by just the slightest aroma of hops and yeast. A light and fluffy mouth feel is emphasized by flavors of cinnamon and vanilla with a pleasant lingering finish that boasts oak and creamy milk chocolate. Excellent.

12oz Bottle. Pours a cloudy amber color but is bright with a medium body. The color hides a continuous stream of bubbles that creates a subtle lining of off white bubbles. On the nose you get overwhelming aromas of spiced apple cider and molasses followed by vanilla and just the slightest hint of wet leather. For a 15% beer the alcohol is hidden incredibly well. Granny smith apples, cinnamon, and molasses prepare the palate for subtle flavors of pepper. Its quite balanced for a barley wine with such a high abv. I didnt think this would be that good. I was pleasantly surprised.

Enjoyed a couple of these at the Falling Rock on Sunday afternoon. As my friend hophead21112 said the aroma of this beer is like a caramel covered grapefruit stuffed with hops. Which would be an accurate deScription of the aroma complete with subtle notes of eucalyptus and pine and beautiful floral undertones. Flawless color, shimmering golden hue with a light head of white bubbles which was a sight considering a very small flow of carbonated bubbles. A very bright mouth feel with citrus that hints at freshly squeezed oranges, followed by the subtle bitterness of hops and just the slightest sting of alcohol. These flavors combine beautifully to create a finish that lingers on the surface of the tongue. It made for a great Sunday. Thank you Russian River and cheers to the Pub Rat.

22oz Bomber -  Pours a burning ruby red with a steady flow of fine bubbles complete with an off white head. The nose is delightfully complex with notes of eucalyptus, raspberries, vanilla, oak and just the slightest scent of anise. The taste is tart at first but relatively dry with a pleasant finish. Flavors of cherries, lemon, vanilla and bourbon coat the tongue and linger in the throat. A well balanced and delicious brew.

Pours thick and black with just the slightest amount of head. Its almost as if the beer is so thick that it suppresses the carbonation. The head is a rich shade of mahogany. On the nose theres an overwhelming aroma of coffee, alcohol, oak, vanilla and roasted malts. The taste is uniquely bitter at first followed by the smooth taste and texture of milk chocolate. The two flavors combine with the powerful alcohol content to create a complex finish.

Margarete was a uniquely intense masterpiece that transformed with every sip. Its dark and rich color was complimented by just the slightest head. At fist the aroma fell short showing only Mephistopheles and bourbon but seconds after notes of chocolate covered cherries, coffee, caramel, graham crackers and coconut creme followed. The taste was just as satisfying as the flavors transformed themselves taste after taste. With a very full mouth feel and an array of flavors this was one of the best beers Avery has produced yet.

The color is a golden amber with just the slightest head and almost a syrupy appearance. Its a good looking beer but I feel like it lacks just a little bit of carbonation. The aroma is increasingly pleasant as this beer gets used to the room. Notes of freshly peeled oranges, pine, and caramel add to the abundance of the powerful hop aroma. These aromas translate wonderfully on the tongue and leaves the mouth and the tongue sticky with hop residue.

Shimmering gold color, light body, slight head. Very pleasing aroma full of complex notes of cardamom, orange peel, citrus, and brandy. The spices can be felt on the tongue followed by a warming sensation of alcohol. Overall a decent mouth feel, but ultimately I feel like it fell a little short.

Murky golden color with a slight head of pearly white bubbles. Very strong aroma of banana on the nose with notes of clove, coriander, pineapple and citrus. Refreshing mouth feel very bright and smooth. One of the better wheat beers out there.

As soon as the cap was popped I could smell sweet sticky hops, whole cones make a difference I suppose. Beautiful amber hue, minimal bubbles, slight head, and a decent lacing. The slight taste of copper is followed by alcohol with a finish of pineapple, citrus and pine. Theres definitely a long finish that sticks to the palate. Good brew.

Maybe once a decade unless you planned ahead, the Jubel 2010 has been enjoyable time and time again. As I was peeling the wax from the cap I could detect notes of wert, caramel, brown sugar, a touch of oak and the mild aroma of yeast. A deep amber color was supported by just the slightest pearly white head. The taste is a complex combination of wheat toast, maple syrup, dark fruit, raspberries, plums, and just the slight sting of alcohol. This one is drinking nice.

A beautiful and rich color that is reinforced by its aroma of toasted coffee beans, semi sweet chocolate, brown sugar and alcohol. The taste is wonderfully bitter but balanced by the sweet taste of chocolate and roasted malts. Delicious.

One of the best beers out there. Pliny is aromatic with overwhelming notes of pine citrus hops and just a little bit of alcohol. Golden in color, clear, perfect bubbles and a beautiful lacing. It has a full mouth feel and the flavors are perfectly balanced. Its sticky with a taste a feel that lasts.

The appearance and aroma of this brew was what stood out. Golden and clean with a great head. On the nose theres the scent of freshly peeled oranges and tangerine. It wasnt as bitter as I would have liked it to be. Flavors of citrus and pine are present but it didnt have much of a finish.

One of the better flavored porters out there. Rich in color light head. I appreciate how the aroma changes as the beer starts to reach room temperature. The aromas are unique. Coconut notes are present, but not overwhelming. Its smooth and creamy with more chocolate and coffee than coconut but it has a pleasant finish.

Pungent. The alcohol is present on the nose but accompanied by black licorice which helps mellow it out. The appearance is bold. Black but with a surprisingly lighter head of rich brown bubbles. Sticky lacing. The taste is unique. Im not a huge black licorice fan so it threw me off a little bit but flavors of toffee and vanilla contribute to create a pleasing combination. Overall I couldnt get over the licorice flavor but that doesnt mean it isnt a beautifully crafted brew. Perfect for this time of year.
